author: By Zachariah Mampilly
title: Protests Are Taking Over the World. What’s Driving Them?
description: Growing economic inequality, climate change and Covid-19. People are demanding a fundamental rethinking of the social contract.
content: September was turbulent: More than 200 Australians arrested during citywide protests and a temporary no-fly zone declared over Melbourne. Rubber bullets and tear gas unleashed by the Thai riot police into an angry crowd. Health care workers assaulted in Canada. Rallies of up to 150,000 people across the Netherlands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Julia Harris
title: Housing Boss Earns $1 Million to Run Shelters Despite a Troubled Past
description: Some executives at nonprofit groups that operate New York City homeless shelters are benefiting from the plight of the people they serve.
content: Soon after Jack A. Brown III quit his job at a private prison company, his former employer accused him of fraud. A few years later, after Mr. Brown started a nonprofit to run halfway houses, a federal audit found that it had failed to deliver key services. The New York State comptroller concluded in another review that Mr. Brown had shown “a disturbing pattern of ethical violations.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Returns With a New President Biden
description: James Austin Johnson, a new cast member, played the president in the cold open. “S.N.L.” also paid tribute to Norm Macdonald, the former Weekend Update anchor, who died last month.
content: It’s a new season at “Saturday Night Live,” which means new cast members — and, surprisingly, a new performer playing President Biden in his first episode on the show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joyce Maynard
title: In Search of Fall Colors: A Long Drive on New Hampshire Roads
description: A novelist looks back on her past as she reveals her favorite autumn spots — and finds some new ones — in her home state.
content: I was born and raised in New Hampshire, and though I have lived many places over the years, I have set nearly every one of my novels in my home state. I give the towns fictional names. But in my head, as I write, I carry pictures of the real places that inspired them and of the seasons in which my stories unfold.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘It Was a Warm Sunday Afternoon at a Bar Near the Brooklyn Waterfront.’
description: A jam session with a twist, a fisherman whistling on the subway and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Chris Cameron
title: Progressives Stand Firm on Priorities as Infrastructure Debate Continues
description: Liberals rejected demands from moderate Democrats to shrink President Biden’s domestic policy agenda by more than half, though they said they were willing to compromise.
content: After a tumultuous week in Congress, during which deep divisions in the Democratic Party delayed progress on part of President Biden’s economic agenda, debate spilled over into the weekend as the party braced for intense negotiations in the weeks ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: How a Tip to Obituaries Breathed New Life Into a Decades-Old Mystery
description: A news assistant on the Obituaries desk describes how information he received while doing a routine part of his job set him on an investigation of a notorious 1975 kidnapping.
content: As the junior member of The Times’s Obituaries desk, I specialize in a duty more esoteric than writing or editing. I keep our list of recent deaths. Every tip from a Times reporter, every voice mail from a mourner and every entreaty from a publicist with a posthumous client — I record them all and ensure that each person they represent has a chance at whatever immortality newsprint offers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Breast Implant Company’s Sponsorship of Women’s Chess Draws Backlash
description: The International Chess Federation’s partnership with Establishment Labs touched off criticism in the chess world, where women say they have long faced unequal treatment and misogyny.
content: The International Chess Federation, the game’s governing body, is facing intense criticism from female chess players and others after announcing that a company that makes breast implants would sponsor women’s chess events.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Stray From a Topic
description: Christina Iverson and Andrea Carla Michaels bring a lovely puzzle into the world.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Happy Monday, folks! Today we have a collaboration between Christina Iverson (making her ninth New York Times Crossword appearance) and Andrea Carla Michaels (making her 76th!). I enjoyed solving this team effort quite a bit, and as so often happens when a song plays a major role in a puzzle (not a spoiler, it’s in the clue for 56A!), I ended up with an earworm that I still have not managed to shake loose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: 8 Things to Do in the Southwest This Fall
description: Hot-air balloons, sandhill cranes, haunted towns and Hatch chiles are just a few signs of fall in New Mexico and Arizona. Here’s where to look.
content: Fall is the onset of outdoor season in the Southwest, when birds return to winter in the mild temperatures, skies clear of the summer monsoons and color tours may entail spotting hundreds of vibrant hot-air balloons. The following are eight seasonal activities in Arizona and New Mexico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: What They Saw in Ozy
description: The story behind the story is about the elite investors who plowed millions into a media dream without much due diligence, persuaded by the charm of Ozy’s head, Carlos Watson.
content: There’s an irresistible temptation, in this age of scams and hype, to obsess about the man or woman at the center of a company’s implosion. Theranos’s Elizabeth Holmes was the subject of an HBO documentary, and is now the center of a high-profile trial. And when Ozy Media collapsed on Friday, less than a week after The New York Times reported on a series of misleading statements and actions, all eyes turned to the man at the center of the company, Carlos Watson, an ambitious dreamer who seemed to believe in what he was selling. When he spoke with me over Zoom from a California backyard on Sunday, he conceded nothing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Sami Sahak and Wali Arian
title: Three Killed and Two Wounded in Explosion Outside a Mosque in Kabul
description: No group immediately claimed responsibility, but the attack resembled others by the Islamic State, which seeks to undermine the Taliban’s rule in Afghanistan.
content: An explosion outside a mosque in the center of Kabul killed at least three people on Sunday, a Taliban spokesman said, underscoring the challenge of maintaining security for the country’s new rulers after decades of waging war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $450,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: Trams, Cable Cars, Electric Ferries: How Cities Are Rethinking Transit
description: Urban transportation is central to the effort to slow climate change. It can’t be done by just switching to electric cars. Several cities are starting to electrify mass transit.
content: The roar of engines has long been part of the soundscape of a city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Gottlieb
title: In Praise of ‘Rationality’
description: In his new book, the Harvard psychologist Steven Pinker makes an argument for rational thinking and reminds us of how it’s done.
content: RATIONALITYWhat It Is, Why It Seems Scarce, Why It MattersBy Steven Pinker
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laurel Graeber
title: In ‘Alma’s Way,’ a Young Latina Thinks for Herself, Like Her Creator
description: Set in the Bronx, the new PBS Kids’ show from Sonia Manzano, who played Maria on “Sesame Street,” promotes diversity and critical thinking.
content: Although Sonia Manzano has won 15 Emmys for television writing and numerous accolades for her decades playing Maria on “Sesame Street,” she couldn’t have been more emphatic — or colorful — when asked if she had ever wanted to develop her own preschool show during all those years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: A Bag Returns From the Year 2000
description: Valentino pulls from its feathered archives as Paris Fashion Week marches on.
content: Fashion Week is back in full force, and there’s a lot to see. Blink (or scroll too fast on Instagram) and you’ll miss the details: tiny bags, tall shoes, feathered hats, leather capes and diamond dog collars. So as part of a new series, Wow Moment, we’ll spotlight things we saw on the runways that delighted or mystified us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani
title: Small Plane Crashes Near Milan, Killing All on Board
description: Eight people died when a passenger plane hit a building shortly after departing from Milan’s Linate Airport.
content: A small plane crashed into an empty building in the outskirts of Milan on Sunday, and its six passengers and two crew members all died, the Italian authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler
title: The Week in Business: Facebook Under Pressure and Ozy Media Shuts Down
description: Facebook  postponed the start of its “Instagram Kids” product and a  Ozy Media shut down, just five days after a report raised questions about its business strategy.
content: Facebook on Monday postponed the start of its Instagram Kids product after concerns were raised about whether Instagram is healthy for young people. Critics have spoken out against the project after a report about it was first leaked back in March, and those concerns gained momentum after a Wall Street Journal investigation surfaced internal research showing that Instagram had found that its app adds to body issues in teenage girls. (Facebook disputed that characterization.) At a Senate hearing on Thursday, lawmakers took sharp aim at the social network. Senator Edward J. Markey, a Democrat from Massachusetts, compared the company to Big Tobacco, “pushing a product that they know is harmful to the health of young people, pushing it to them early.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dara Horn
title: What Happens When the Last Jew Leaves Afghanistan
description: Stories about the end of diversity aren't charming.
content: The Last Jew of Afghanistan is gone, and everyone is glad to be rid of him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Andrew Wiggins, the Warriors guard who resisted a Covid shot, has gotten one, his coach says.
description: Wiggins will be able to play in home games in San Francisco, since city ordinances require individuals to be fully vaccinated to enter facilities such as indoor gyms.
content: Andrew Wiggins, the Golden State Warriors guard who had resisted getting a Covid-19 vaccine, has received one, the team’s coach, Steve Kerr, told reporters on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Democratic Voters See Many Losers in Party Schism, and One Winner: Trump
description: In a New Jersey district represented by one of the conservative-leaning Democrats in the House, Democratic voters are disappointed and worried by the party’s inability to pass President Biden’s agenda.
content: RIDGEWOOD, N.J. — On Election Day in 2018, Cathy Brienza opened her light blue colonial in a New Jersey suburb to dozens of Democratic activists for a get-out-the-vote rally. A freshman congressman, Josh Gottheimer, addressed a crowd filled with voters angered by Donald J. Trump’s presidency and hopeful of regaining Democratic control of the House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: ‘Saildrone’ Footage Offers Rare Peek Inside a Category 4 Hurricane
description: The 23-foot crewless vessel pierced the eyewall of Hurricane Sam and captured stunning images as the storm barreled through the Atlantic Ocean.
content: The video looks like it could be b-roll from the 2000 film “The Perfect Storm.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hari Kumar, Mujib Mashal and Atul Loke
title: They Helped Build Modern India but Are Shrinking as a People
description: Parsis have supported many of the country’s institutions and nurtured business and the arts. But their numbers have dwindled at an alarming pace.
content: UDVADA, India — From the porch of his century-old home, Khurshed Dastoor has a front-row seat to a tragedy that he fears may be too late to reverse: the slow extinction of a people who helped build modern India.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: The Yankees (Mostly) Control Their Fate on Season’s Final Day
description: Wins by the Yankees and the Red Sox would give both teams wild-card spots in the playoffs. A loss by either team, or both, could extend the regular season.
content: The Yankees will play further into October after Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nadja Spiegelman
title: From Miriam Toews, a Tragicomedy About the Dysfunctional World of Adults
description: “Fight Night” is the story of three generations of women as told by the youngest of them.
content: FIGHT NIGHT By Miriam Toews
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Crouse
title: I Used to Look Up to Elizabeth Holmes
description: The Theranos founder has turned out to be a symbol of how far we haven’t come.
content: When I was a student at Harvard in the early aughts, Mark Zuckerberg and some other classmates dropped out to become the young kings of tech. They were smart, competitive and hard-working — like most people there. But I never could exactly relate. They had a confidence that was hard to describe, a peculiar kind of ambition that seemed to all but entitle them to success. As I got older, I realized the quality I was imagining as special wasn’t. They were just men.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Oct. 4, 2021
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: If Men Needed the Abortions …
description: It feels like Roe v. Wade is under threat in a way that it hasn’t been in recent memory.
content: On Thursday, three women of color — sitting members of Congress — testified before the House Committee on Oversight and Reform about abortions they had received, describing, in some cases, the stigma attached to them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Blinken Faces an Awkward Visit to Paris, His ‘Second Home’
description: The secretary of state’s close ties with France will be valuable in smoothing over the diplomatic spat last month over a U.S. submarine deal with Australia.
content: WASHINGTON — The reception could hardly have been warmer when Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken appeared in France’s ornate foreign ministry building on a late June day alongside his French counterpart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Review: In ‘Upload,’ Do Blockchains Dream of Electric Lizards?
description: Michel van der Aa’s new opera weaves technology into a traditional form with masterly restraint for a sci-fi spin on a fundamentally human tale.
content: AMSTERDAM — “I’m here, that’s for sure!” the digital facsimile of a father tells his daughter early in Michel van der Aa’s new opera, “Upload.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Female Soccer Players Are Done Taking Abuse. Let’s Stop Dishing It Out.
description: Players in the National Women’s Soccer League are demanding the respect all female athletes deserve but rarely get.
content: When will we stop treating women in sports as second-class citizens?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Musicians Flee Afghanistan, Fearing Taliban Rule
description: Dozens of artists and teachers from a prominent music school that promoted girls’ education left the country, but more remain behind. “The mission is not complete,” its founder said.
content: More than 100 young artists, teachers and their relatives affiliated with the Afghanistan National Institute of Music, a celebrated school that became a target of the Taliban in part for its efforts to promote the education of girls, fled the country on Sunday, the school’s leaders said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: ‘Crazy, Wild, Tough Year’ Continues as Yankees Clinch Wild Card
description: On a day that looked like a recipe for chaos, the Yankees and the Red Sox made things simple by winning. They will face each other in Boston with a division series trip on the line.
content: The Yankees chased Aaron Judge into the outfield early Sunday night, swarming him in a bouncy, gleeful embrace. Now they will follow Judge to the playoffs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Aufderheide
title: Don’t Let Amazon Eat the Film Industry
description: Unlike any other streamer, Amazon brings hundreds of billions of dollars in revenue and the power of a vast network of other lines of business to the fight.
content: In the 1930s and ’40s, five major Hollywood studios dominated the film industry and tried to lock up distribution and exhibition channels as well by taking over movie theaters across the country. Courts and regulators saw that allowing studios so much power up and down the film supply chain posed grave threats to the integrity of the industry and to viewer choice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Back on the Bench, the Supreme Court Faces a Blockbuster Term
description: The court, which is dominated by six Republican appointees, will confront a charged docket, including a case asking it to overrule Roe v. Wade.
content: WASHINGTON — A transformed Supreme Court returns to the bench on Monday to start a momentous term in which it will consider eliminating the constitutional right to abortion, vastly expanding gun rights and further chipping away at the wall separating church and state.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘I Had a Chance to Travel Anywhere. Why Did I Pick Spokane?’
description: After 18 months of pandemic parenting isolation, one writer knew just where the cure might lie: a minor-league baseball game in eastern Washington.
content: Jon Mooallem, the author of today’s Sunday Read, had a bad pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo
title: Vietnamese Americans, Once Displaced Themselves, Mobilize to Help Afghans
description: For many who made it to the United States, watching the chaotic exit from Afghanistan evoked memories of their own harrowing experiences.
content: In the middle of the night, Uyen Nguyen trudged through a grassy marshland with her mother and three siblings until they reached the edge of the ocean, where a small, dilapidated fishing boat was beached on the sand. It set off with 31 people packed on it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Jordan’s King Among Leaders Accused of Amassing Secret Property Empire
description: A leak of nearly 12 million files suggested King Abdullah II was among 35 current and former leaders to use secret shell companies to hide their wealth.
content: GAZA CITY — King Abdullah II of Jordan came under heightened scrutiny on Sunday after an alliance of international news organizations reported that he was among several world leaders to use secret offshore accounts to amass overseas properties and hide their wealth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley and Amy Qin
title: In a Surge of Military Flights, China Tests and Warns Taiwan
description: For two straight days, Beijing sent a record number of planes near the island, Taiwan said, a display of strength that underscored Chinese demands for unification.
content: Record-breaking numbers of Chinese military planes probed the airspace near Taiwan over the weekend, prompting Taiwanese fighter jets to scramble and adding muscle to Beijing’s warnings that it could ultimately use force to take hold of the island.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson
title: The Delta variant caused a spike in deaths among nursing home residents, study finds.
description: Nursing homes reported nearly 1,800 deaths among their residents and staff in August, the highest monthly toll since February.
content: Although nursing home deaths from Covid-19 remain dramatically down from their peak at the end of last year, a Kaiser Family Foundation analysis shows a significant uptick in August as the Delta variant swept through the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac and Cecilia Kang
title: Whistle-Blower Says Facebook ‘Chooses Profits Over Safety’
description: Frances Haugen, a Facebook product manager who left the company in May, revealed that she had provided internal documents to journalists and others.
content: John Tye, the founder of Whistleblower Aid, a legal nonprofit that represents people seeking to expose potential lawbreaking, was contacted this spring through a mutual connection by a woman who claimed to have worked at Facebook.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Oct. 3, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Oct. 3, 2021.
content: The dance listings in the New Season issue on Sept. 19 misstated the dates of Caleb Teicher’s “Swing Out” at the Joyce Theater. Performances are Oct. 5-17, not Oct. 15-17.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Diapers Are the Latest Pandemic Shortage
description: A police bulletin seeking information on a man recorded shoplifting packages of diapers drew fresh attention to a continuing crisis of access to the product, according to the National Diaper Bank Network.
content: “Anyone recognize him?” the police in Winter Haven, Fla., asked on Facebook last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Sloss
title: Setting Sail on the Winding Waterways of California’s Delta
description: The sprawling 1,250-square-mile system of water and farmland in Northern California is a four-season destination for watersport fans and home to many riverbank communities.
content: The wind was a perfect 20 knots, the warm breeze filling our sails, as we angled westward, riding the current down the Sacramento River. We sailed past Sherman Island, slowly cruising through a group of kiteboarders and windsurfers who flew by our hull throwing peace signs. The Montezuma Hills rolled leisurely to the west, dotted with a mass of languorous windmills while tule reeds, permanently slanting eastward, shuddered as a flight of swallows rose in unison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold and Melissa Eddy
title: Skateboards, Climate Change and Freedom: Germany’s Next-Generation Parliament
description: A new generation of lawmakers is entering Germany’s Parliament. They felt ignored by the previous government, so they set out to change that by winning elections.
content: BERLIN — Emilia Fester is 23 and has yet to finish college. Max Lucks is 24 and calls himself a militant cyclist. Ria Schröder is 29 and has the rainbow flag on her Twitter profile. Muhanad Al-Halak is 31 and came to Germany from Iraq when he was 11.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Sights on U.S., Migrants Flood Perilous Jungle
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, October 3, 2021.
content: “We very well could be on the precipice of a historic displacement of people in the Americas toward the United States. When one of the most impenetrable stretches of jungle in the world is no longer stopping people, it underscores that political borders, however enforced, won’t either.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: We’re All On the Red Carpet Now
description: Balenciaga holds the smartest show of the week. Valentino takes to the streets. And Hermès gets grounded.
content: PARIS — The marquee outside the Théâtre du Châtelet, the gilded 19th-century musical theater on the Right Bank, cast a red glow over the fans thronged rows deep in the square outside on Saturday night. A forest of smartphones was held aloft, waving in the night air like a host of alien palm fronds, as various black cars pulled up to disgorge their guests. Penned-in photographers hovered behind a velvet rope while men and women swaggered their way across the red carpet, posing, waving, preening and otherwise camping it up on their way inside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Clint Eastwood Wins $6.1 Million CBD Lawsuit
description: The Academy Award-winning director accused a Lithuanian company of falsely claiming that he had endorsed CBD products.
content: The actor Clint Eastwood and Garrapata, the company that owns the rights to his likeness, were awarded $6.1 million on Friday in a lawsuit they had filed against a Lithuanian company that was accused of using Mr. Eastwood’s image and likeness to make it appear as though he was endorsing their products.Last year, Mr. Eastwood filed two lawsuits in federal court in Los Angeles against three CBD manufacturers and marketers whose products were featured in an online article falsely claiming that he endorsed CBD products, as well as 10 online retailers who he accused of manipulating search results through meta tags. (CBD is cannabidiol, a nonintoxicating compound in the cannabis sativa plant.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: In Alaska’s Covid Crisis, Doctors Must Decide Who Lives and Who Dies
description: Amid the nation’s worst Covid-19 outbreak, patients are trapped in remote communities and doctors are prioritizing treatment based on who is most likely to survive.
content: ANCHORAGE — There was one bed coming available in the intensive care unit in Alaska’s largest hospital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Saints Finally Return Home, to a City That Needed Them
description: The team evacuated New Orleans on Aug. 28, the day before Hurricane Ida made landfall, and returned to play its first true home game of the season, a 27-21 loss to the Giants.
content: NEW ORLEANS — The locals streamed down Poydras Street toward the Superdome, walking past tree limbs, over downed poles and through intersections where lights blinked only red. Once they were inside together, they released what the jazz trumpeter Kermit Ruffins last week called the most beautiful sound in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: A Prank Gift Propels an Underdog to New Heights in the Marathon
description: Keira D’Amato thought her dreams of a professional running career were over. Now, as a 36-year-old mother of two, she’s a podium contender at the Chicago Marathon.
content: Keira D’Amato had let her running dreams go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and Melina Delkic
title: ‘Major’ Oil Spill Off California Coast Threatens Wetlands and Wildlife
description: A pipeline failure sent at least 126,000 gallons of oil into the Pacific off the coast of Orange County, creating a 13-square-mile slick. Dead fish and birds washed ashore in some areas.
content: A pipeline failure off the coast of Orange County, Calif., on Saturday caused at least 126,000 gallons of oil to spill into the Pacific Ocean, creating a 13-square-mile slick that continued to grow on Sunday, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marissa Hermanson
title: 8 Places to Visit Along Virginia’s Blue Ridge Parkway
description: With an autumnal ombré and cooler temperatures, fall is prime time for journeying along this Appalachian Mountain roadway.
content: With its sweeping vistas and meandering nature, the Blue Ridge Parkway is a scenic delight year-round. But fall is the most celebrated season on the Appalachian Mountain road, when the winding two-lane boulevard is a spectacle with the golden glow of leaves and cool mountain mist. And as we continue to worry about the spread of the coronavirus, a road trip with fresh air and panoramic views lends itself nicely to traveling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser
title: Biden, Supreme Court, Cider: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brendan Spiegel
title: Following the Shamrocks on a Canadian Road Trip
description: Discovering fields of green and Celtic culture on a coastal drive along Newfoundland’s Irish Loop.
content: “It looks like the edge of the world out here,” my wife, Holly, mused, not disapprovingly. Our picnic blanket was spread out on a high cliff, with green-capped rock stretching alongside us, endless blue ocean in front. It was the first of many leisurely breaks we would take on our slow road trip through Newfoundland’s Avalon Peninsula.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Dunne
title: What We Learned From Week 4 of the N.F.L. Season
description: Cowboys quarterback Dak Prescott is sitting on top of Jerry’s World, the Giants got an instructive win, and Kirk Cousins reverted to form in the Vikings’ loss.
content: Utterly dismantling a Carolina Panthers defense that has dominated the rest of the N.F.L. this season, Dak Prescott looked like a Super Bowl-caliber quarterback that Jerry Jones doubted he ever would be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: The Slugging Rays Find Yet Another Way to Be Different
description: With a low payroll that requires some trade-offs, Tampa Bay leads the majors in runs despite leading the A.L. in strikeouts.
content: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Chad Mottola was sure he was done with baseball. He had given 16 years to the game, all to get 25 hits in the majors and a thousand restless nights in the minors. Nagging questions would swirl through his brain at odd hours: How could he change his swing? Would he ever get another call to the majors? Should he quit?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israel will require a booster shot to be considered fully vaccinated.
description: The vaccination passports of more than a million people will soon be canceled if they don’t get a booster or show that they recently had Covid.
content: JERUSALEM — Israel on Sunday introduced new rules for determining coronavirus vaccination status, making a booster shot a requirement for full inoculation and vaccination passports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf and Sangar Khaleel
title: 3,000 Yazidis Are Still Missing. Their Families Know Where Some of Them Are.
description: Seven years after they were captured by the Islamic State, some members of the Iraqi religious minority are still being held captive by fighters in Syria. Others are with families of ISIS militants.
content: The voice messages sent by Abbas Hussein’s teenage son are heartbreaking in their matter-of-factness. The boy, a member of Iraq’s Yazidi minority who was kidnapped by Islamic State fighters seven years ago, asks about his mother and wonders why his father has not been in touch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: China probes Taiwan’s airspace.
content: For two straight days, China sent a record number of planes in its direction, Taiwan said, a display of strength that added muscle to Beijing’s warnings that it could ultimately use force to take hold of the self-ruled island.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: Want to Change the World? First, Be Still.
description: Advocacy for the oppressed requires action — but also silence and contemplation.
content: When I was in college, I met a chain-smoking Franciscan priest who changed my life. He was a chaplain at my university and, like all Franciscans, had taken a vow of poverty. He was smart and compassionate, and I could not doubt his commitment to the marginalized.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Angelo Codevilla, Whose Writings Anticipated Trumpism, Dies at 78
description: A hawkish conservative, he believed that America was hamstrung at home and abroad by a progressive ruling class.
content: Angelo M. Codevilla, a conservative political theorist whose writings in the 1980s helped define the hawkish wing of the Republican Party and later, over the last decade, both predicted and gave intellectual shape to the populist revolt against the party’s establishment, died on Sept. 20 in Tracy, Calif.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan and Jennifer Steinhauer
title: Military Bases Turn Into Small Cities as Afghans Wait Months for Homes in U.S.
description: An estimated 53,000 evacuees from Kabul remain on eight military bases across the country. Thousands more are waiting at U.S. bases abroad to come to the United States.
content: FORT MCCOY, Wis. — In late August, evacuees from Afghanistan began arriving by the busload to the Fort McCoy Army base in the Midwest, carrying little more than cellphones and harrowing tales of their narrow escapes from a country they may never see again. They were greeted by soldiers, assigned rooms in white barracks and advised not to stray into the surrounding forest, lest they get lost.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pierre-Antoine Louis and Dieu Nalio Chery
title: In Their Words: Haitian Immigrants in New York Describe Perilous Escape
description: Dieu Nalio Chery, a photojournalist, fled Haiti after gangs threatened his life. His latest subjects are others who, like him, are far from home.
content: As a young man, Dieu Nalio Chery fell in love with photography while working in his uncle’s photo studio in Port-au-Prince, Haiti. But after a powerful earthquake devastated the country in 2010, he turned what had been a freelance pursuit into a profession, going to work for The Associated Press in Haiti.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Diante Lee and Devin Gordon
title: Are the Giants and Jets Watchable Yet?
description: We enlisted two experts — one locally focused, one nationally — to offer their opinions on the first winning weekend of the 2021 N.F.L. season.
content: This season, we’ve enlisted two experts — one familiar with the ins and outs of New York’s football teams, the other a nationally focused football analyst — to answer an essential question as a service to readers: Are these teams good yet?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: He’s Australia’s Most Decorated Soldier. Did He Also Kill Helpless Afghans?
description: Ben Roberts-Smith is suing three newspapers that accused him of unlawful killings in Afghanistan. But much more than the reputation of one soldier is at stake.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — The elite Australian troops stormed into a mud-walled Afghan village in the late summer of 2012 on a white-hot mission.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: Alessandro Nivola Put His Foot Down and Won the ‘Many Saints’ Role Anyway
description: When he landed his first major lead in 25 years, he sobbed. “I’d been down that road so many times, and the number of disappointments I can’t count on 10 hands.”
content: The throbbing in the back of Alessandro Nivola’s head was growing more intense.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘The Nosebleed’ Review: ‘Who Here Hates Their Father?’
description: Aya Ogawa’s gentle, forthright reckoning of a play is a belated processing of the loss of a parent by a daughter who now has children of her own.
content: “Who here has a father who has died?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson
title: Fauci says Americans should get vaccinated even if Merck’s Covid pill cuts deaths.
description: President Biden’s Covid adviser also says it is “too soon to tell” if the Delta surge will decline enough to allow safe gatherings around the holidays.
content: As the nation’s death toll climbed above 700,000 in October, Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, an adviser on the pandemic to President Biden, emphasized the need for the 70 million Americans who are eligible for a vaccine to get immunized during interviews on Sunday morning talk shows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti, Ella Koeze and Denise Lu
title: How Texas Plans to Make Its House Districts Even Redder
description: The new district lines proposed by Texas Republicans aim to lock in the party’s advantage in Washington over the next decade by building on a previously gerrymandered map.
content: The new district lines proposed by Texas Republicans aim to lock in the party’s advantage in Washington over the next decade by building on a previously gerrymandered map.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Plane Crash Kills 8 Near Milan
description: The small passenger plane hit an empty building after taking off from Milan.
content: The small passenger plane hit an empty building after taking off from Milan.
source.name: The New York Times

title: As I Was Saying: The Etiquette of Interruption
description: Interrupting a speaker: rudeness or cooperation? Also: Work and values; a presidential age limit; Trump's response to a tell-all book; plastic waste.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Thoughts on hollandaise, and recipes for the coming days.
content: Good morning. Is this the day I convince you to roast a duck just so you can shred the meat and scatter it over sautéed sea scallops, then serve the combination with hollandaise sauce, alongside a peppery watercress salad? I’m hoping so! You don’t even need to roast a whole duck. A couple of legs will do, cooked low and slow in a kind of confit situation. Shred them when they’re done, make the hollandaise, the salad and then the scallops. Bang, zoom. That’s a Sunday night feast.
source.name: The New York Times
